poem:
**On Shouk's Closure**

Olive oil  
spills, unbidden—  
a Mediterranean distance  
between tables.  
  
Hummus dreams  
whisper parsley secrets,  
lost in the chatter  
of boycotts, borders.  
  
Empty chairs  
hold questions,  
while the kitchen cooling—  
sighs.  
  
In silence,  
the last crumb falls,  
a diaspora  
of taste  
forgotten.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Boycotting Israel has gone mainstream: ‘We’ve never seen such traction before’ For more than a decade Shouk offered an Israeli-inspired, plant-based and kosher menu in and around Washington. Last week the chain was forced to close the last of five locations and lay off the last of 30 staff. It said the war in Gaza had made it impossible to do business; activists claimed the restaurant appropriated Palestinian food and imported Israeli products. “It didn’t". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
